sections.title: Why should we learn life support?
B asic Life Support        vs      Advanced Life Support
Why should we learn Life Support
Non-shockable rhthms Asystole       & Pulseless Electrical activity
Look, Listen, Feel (with cautions-due to Covid)
Breaths mouth to mouth breathing-not done now

blocks.content: Dr. Saman Nanayakkara Senior Lecturer in Anaesthesiology Faculty of Dental Sciences
Absence of normal breathing in a non- responsive victim
◼ Medical staff can feel for pulse
◼ Brain - very vulnerable to Hypoxic/ Ischaemic injury (3-4 min)
◼ No time to learn/ refer to texts/ consult etc
◼ Whoever who is present has to perform Life support-at the site
◼ Early recognition and call for Help
◼ Maintaining airway, Supporting breathing & circulation without the support of equipment other than protective devices.
if there is a defibrillator nearby
Otherwise start chest compressions, till a defibrillator arrives
◼ See whether its safe to approach
◼ Open the airway-head tilt & chin lift
◼ Check for breathing ( & pulse by medical staff simultaneously)
◼ Look, Listen & Feel (Listen & feel need not be done on unknown patients)
◼ If there is no response, no breathing & no pulse-it's a cardiac arrest.
1. Open the airway Head tilt Chin lift Jaw thrust 2. Clear the airway Suck out Wipe Finger sweep 3.    Maintain patency
◼ Maintain patency of the airway Manually- by head tilt, chin lift etc
◼ Definitive airway Intubation with an Endotracheal  Tube
◼ Alternative airways with less skilled hands Laryngeal Mask Airway LMA
Tight seal around the victim's mouth
◼ See the chest rising and falling
◼ With chest compressions at a rate of 30:2
◼ After intubation- no need to co-ordinate with chest compressions
◼ For a loved one -Cover the face by a cellophane, Chest compressions only CPR
◼ For an unknown person -wear PPE, no aerosol generation procedures, clean the area till help comes with PPE, iv cannula-drip, defibrillation

minimal airway suctioning can do mask ventilation by a trained person minimal mask ventilation can use a LMA even with LMA chest compressions to ventilation is 30:2 early intubation and a viral filter

◼ Defibrillate straightaway

if there is a defibrillator nearby

Otherwise start chest compressions, till a defibrillator arrives

[IMAGE: ]

ALS

◼ See whether its safe to approach

◼ Check for responsiveness

◼ Open the airway-head tilt & chin lift

◼ Check for breathing ( & pulse by medical staff simultaneously)

◼ Look, Listen & Feel (Listen & feel need not be done on unknown patients)

◼ If there is no response, no breathing & no pulse-it's a cardiac arrest.
1. Open the airway Head tilt Chin lift Jaw thrust 2. Clear the airway Suck out Wipe Finger sweep 3.    Maintain patency

◼ Maintain patency of the airway Manually- by head tilt, chin lift etc

◼ Airway adjuncts Airways-Oropharyngeal, Nasopharyngeal

◼ Definitive airway Intubation with an Endotracheal  Tube

◼ Alternative airways with less skilled hands Laryngeal Mask Airway LMA

[IMAGE: ]

[IMAGE: ]

◼ Start artificial breaths

With 2 rescue breaths

Open the airway

Pinch the nostrils

Take a deep breath

Tight seal around the victim's mouth

Deliver 2 breaths

[IMAGE: ]

[IMAGE: ]

[IMAGE: ]

[IMAGE: ]

[IMAGE: ]

◼ See the chest rising and falling

◼ With chest compressions at a rate of 30:2

◼ After intubation- no need to co-ordinate with chest compressions

continue at a rate of 12-14/min

◼ Wear PPE (Personal protective gear)

◼ No need to do-listen & feel

◼ For a loved one -Cover the face by a cellophane, Chest compressions only CPR

◼ For an unknown person -wear PPE, no aerosol generation procedures, clean the area till help comes with PPE, iv cannula-drip, defibrillation
